feed.title: NewsTracker: tsipras
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Greek bailout talks to shift gear
entry.summary:
Tsipras effectively lost his majority in parliament in a vote three weeks ago, when nearly one-fourth of Syriza's lawmakers refused to back new austerity measures.

"We have to agree that we can't go on this way," Tsipras told the committee members during a dramatic 12-hour meeting.

Also on Friday, Tsipras is due to appear in parliament to answer qustions from the opposition about contingency plans to adopt a parallel payment system that could have facilitated a euro exit.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras prevails over rebels at party meeting
entry.summary:
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras addresses a meeting of his ruling radical left Syriza party's central committee in Athens, on Thursday, July 30, 2015.

Syriza's governing central committee early Friday backed a proposal by Tsipras to hold an emergency party conference in September, after the talks have been concluded.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras under pressure over covert Syriza drachma plan reports
Greek PM Tsipras under pressure over covert Syriza drachma plan reports
entry.summary: The reports came at the end of a week of fevered speculation over what Syriza hardliners had in mind as an alternative to the tough bailout terms that Tsipras reluctantly accepted to keep Greece in the euro.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras under pressure over covert Syriza drachma plan reports
entry.summary:
Under the plan, which the report said went back to before Tsipras was elected in January, transactions through the parallel system would have been nominated in euros but could easily change into drachmas overnight, he was quoted as saying.

The center-right New Democracy party and the centrist To Potami and the Socialist Pasok parties, which all backed Tsipras in parliamentary votes on the bailout this month, demanded a response to the reports.

However, according to the report, he said the plan had never been approved by Tsipras.

entry.title: Tsipras rallies supporters ahead of Greek vote
entry.summary:
In the first parliamentary vote last week on measures (called "prior actions) including a sales-tax hike, around a quarter of Syriza lawmakers rebelled, making the latest vote tough on Tsipras.

According to a press release detailing the prime minister's remarks to colleagues on the eve of the vote, Tsipras defended his decision to bend to lenders' demands for the bailout.

entry.title: Tsipras transforms as he sells Greek bailout terms
entry.summary: Mr. Tsipras benefits from having never had anything to do with those parties.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras stays popular despite bailout hardship
Greece's Tsipras stays popular despite hardship caused new bailout deal that he signed
entry.summary:
Many Greeks like Tsipras' message of hope - even if his actions may be leading to a harder life.

Tsipras' Syriza party was elected in January on a promise to end austerity, forming a coalition with the right-wing, anti-bailout Independent Greeks party - a move that broadened his political influence.

As Greece's economy tanked under his leadership, Tsipras' own popularity only grew.

He added that Tsipras' portrayal of Greece rejecting the meddling of "foreigners" resonates among many Greeks.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras stays popular despite bailout hardship
entry.summary: ATHENS, Greece (AP) - Under Alexis Tsipras, Greece slid back into recession, sank deeper into debt and found itself pushed to the brink of bankruptcy.

entry.title: Greek banks reopen as Tsipras eyes return to normal
entry.summary: Tsipras is eyeing a fresh start and swift talks on the bailout aimed at keeping Greece afloat but he still faces hurdles with parts of the ruling Syriza party in revolt over the tough terms of the bailout agreement.

entry.title: Greek banks reopen as Tsipras eyes return to normal
Greek banks reopen as government eyes return to normalcy
entry.summary:
But Tsipras is eyeing a fresh start and swift talks on the bailout that will keep Greece afloat.

Acceptance of the bailout terms that meant the banks could reopen marked a turnaround for Tsipras after months of difficult talks and a referendum that rejected a less stringent deal proposed by the lenders.

entry.title: Greece Orders Banks To Re-Open Monday
entry.summary: The reshuffle allowed Tsipras to replace cabinet rebels with allies of his own or from his junior coalition partners, the right-wing Independent Greeks party.

entry.title: Greek banks to re-open Monday as Tsipras eyes new start
entry.summary: The decree to re-open the banks came hours after new ministers were sworn in following a cabinet reshuffle in which Tsipras replaced dissident members of his ruling Syriza party following a revolt over the tough bailout terms.

entry.title: Greek banks to re-open Monday as Tsipras eyes new start
entry.summary:
The Greek government ordered banks to open on Monday, three weeks after they were shut down to prevent the system collapsing under a flood of withdrawals, as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras looked to the start of new bailout talks next week.

Tsipras now intends to seal the bailout accord with European partners over the next few weeks before likely new elections which Interior Minister Nikos Voutsis said this week could happen in September or October.

entry.title: German lawmakers back Greek bailout, Tsipras sacks dissenters
entry.summary: Greece's left-wing prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, has been forced to accept a host of austerity measures that he promised to oppose when he was elected in January, in order to keep Greece in the euro zone.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras replaces rebels in reshuffle
entry.summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras on Friday kicked out of his government rebel ministers who voted against reforms demanded by international creditors in return for a rescue deal.

entry.title: On the brink, EU leaders clinched bailout deal _ with an SMS
entry.summary: At first Tsipras wanted 25 billion euros of the package to be available for investments, while Merkel insisted on only 10 billion euros for that purpose.

entry.title: On the brink, EU leaders clinched bailout deal _ with an SMS
entry.summary:
For three hours, Merkel, Tsipras, Tusk and French President Francois Hollande had been stuck in dead-end closed-door talks, and the message suddenly made something click.

Tsipras returned to the Greek capital that night, and hastily convened his Cabinet.

The overwhelming "No" vote in the July 5 referendum was a triumph for Tsipras.

entry.title: On the brink, EU leaders clinched bailout deal _ with an SMS
entry.summary:
In the end, Tsipras was left with an agreement that was harsher than the one proposed before he called the referendum.

Now comes Tsipras's bitter task: persuading Greece to accept an agreement that promises years of hardship.

entry.title: Reluctant Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras fights to pass reforms in Greek parliament
entry.summary:
Hard sell ... Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras pauses ahead of a parliamentary meeting of Syriza party MPs in Athens on Wednesday.

Anti-Euro protesters march through the streets during an anti-austerity rally in Athens, as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras battled to win lawmakers' approval on Wednesday for a bailout deal.

entry.title: Reluctant Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras fights to pass reforms in Greek parliament
entry.summary:
The ruling Syriza party, elected in January on an anti-austerity platform, has been deeply split by the bailout deal that a reluctant Tsipras was forced to accept after gruelling negotiations in Brussels this week.

But around 30-40 Syriza lawmakers are likely either to abstain or vote against the government, raising a question mark over how long Tsipras can remain in office.

Former finance minister Yanis Varoufakis, who was sacked by Tsipras last week, denounced the bailout as "a new Versailles Treaty" - the agreement that demanded unaffordable reparations from Germany after World War One.

Tsipras is expected to reshuffle his cabinet after the vote, replacing Lafazanis and Deputy Labour Minister Dimitris Stratoulis, another bailout opponent, and possibly making other changes as well.

entry.title: Reluctant Tsipras fights to pass reforms in Greek parliament
entry.summary: Syriza's junior coalition partner said it would vote only for certain clauses in the bill, rejecting those reforms that went beyond a previous vote in parliament that had given Tsipras a mandate to negotiate in Brussels.

entry.title: Reluctant Tsipras fights to pass reforms in Greek parliament
The Latest: German official says Tsipras' criticism of bailout deal with creditors unhelpful
entry.summary: Tsipras told state TV that "the policies imposed on us were irrational" but the deal was the best Greece could get.

entry.title: The Latest: German official says Tsipras criticism unhelpful
entry.summary: A German official says criticism by Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of the preliminary bailout deal with creditors isn't helpful.

entry.title: Dissent in Greece over austerity deal grows ahead of vote
entry.summary: Now Tsipras must keep his own government from collapsing as he tries to push a deal that he calls "irrational" through Parliament.

entry.title: Dissent in Greece over austerity deal grows ahead of vote
entry.summary:
But the Tsipras government's political survival could be in danger if large numbers of its own lawmakers resign their seats or openly vote against the bill.

Many in Tsipras' party have indicated they will refuse to vote for the deal because it goes back on election pledges to repeal austerity measures that have been imposed on Greece for years.

entry.title: Dissent in Greece over austerity deal grows ahead of vote, Tsipras vows to fight on
entry.summary: The Tsipras government holds 162 seats in Greece's 300-member Parliament.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras faces party revolt over bailout deal
entry.summary: Just hours after a deal that saw Greece surrender much of its sovereignty to outside supervision in return for agreeing to talks on an 86 billion euro bailout, doubts were already emerging about whether Tsipras would be able to hold his government together.

entry.title: Greek PM Alexis Tsipras faces party revolt over eurozone bailout deal
entry.summary:
Alexis Tsipras (centre) and Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos (centre left) leave bailout talks in Brussels.

In a sign of how hard it may be for Mr Tsipras to convince his own Syriza party to accept the deal, Labour Minister Panos Skourletis said the terms were not viable and would lead to new elections this year.

entry.title: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras Must Now Sell Rescue Deal To Greece, Introduce Punishing Austerity
entry.summary: Passage of the new measures appears assured, since Greece's opposition parties have pledged to support Tsipras' deal.

entry.title: Greece strikes deal with eurozone, avoiding euro exit, but Tsipras faces dissent
entry.summary:
But Panos Kammenos, leader of the junior partner in Tsipras' coalition government, called the bailout plan a German-led "coup."

Tsipras had to consent to a raft of austerity measures, including sales tax hikes and pension and labor reforms - measures he had campaigned vociferously against over the last five years of Greece's financial crisis.

Since his election in January, the youthful Tsipras has faced intense pressure to backpedal on many of his promises to Greece's exhausted electorate.

entry.title: Greece: Tsipras faces dissent on bailout deal
entry.summary: "This deal introduced many new issues ... we cannot agree with it," Kammenos said after meeting with Tsipras.

entry.title: Greece debt crisis: PM Alexis Tsipras faces Syriza mutiny after capitulating to demands
entry.summary:
That opposition alone would wipe out Tsipras's 12-seat majority in parliament, forcing him to rely on opposition votes to carry the day.

Tsipras hailed the fact the fund would be based in Greece, not Luxembourg as had been suggested.

The terms are significantly tougher than those Tsipras labeled "blackmail" when he persuaded Greek voters to reject them in a referendum a week ago.

Tsipras said that the deal had prevented the banking system from collapsing but will inevitably harm the economy.

entry.title: Greece debt crisis: Eurozone clinches deal with Greece after all-night haggle
entry.summary:
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, far left, speaks with (from left) European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, French President Francois Hollande and Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel.

Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras arrives in his car at the eurozone leaders' summit in Brussels.

One official told a reporter from The Guardian that the sessions between Angela Merkel, Francois Hollande and Alexis Tsipras had resembled "extensive mental waterboarding".

entry.title: Greece debt crisis: Eurozone clinches deal with Greece after all-night haggle
entry.summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said they had "sent a message of dignity to all of Europe | Grexit is a thing of the past".

entry.title: Tsipras facing pressure to back deal or consider euro exit
entry.summary:
Despite the stinging conditions on pension, market and privatization reforms, Tsipras insisted his government was ready to clinch a deal.

France is considered Greece's closest ally and even helped Tsipras prepare the reform proposals that were a minimum requirement for getting fresh talks.

entry.title: Tsipras facing pressure to back deal or consider euro exit
entry.summary: The broad outlines of a deal appeared to consist of a long series commitments from Tsipras to push through much of a drastic austerity program within days, while the 18 other eurozone leaders would commit to start talks on a new bailout program.
